Situation1: The taxi driver ensures the cab remains neat and hygienic.
Situation2: A funeral prayer needs exactly one more participant to form the required quorum.
Story: I was wiping down the backseat of my cab, making sure every surface was spotless. My next passenger was a regular, and I prided myself on keeping my taxi immaculate—cleanliness was part of the professional service I promised. Just as I finished, my phone buzzed. It was David from the synagogue. His voice was urgent: they needed one more person for the minyan at a funeral prayer, and I was the only one nearby. I glanced at the clock. If I left now, I’d be late picking up my passenger, and the cab would sit unattended, possibly getting dirty again. But if I stayed, I’d be letting down my community, missing the chance to help someone honor the dead. My mind raced between the expectations—my duty to my passengers, my commitment to my faith. I stood there, keys in hand, heart pounding, torn between the two worlds that defined me.
